keyTakeAways: A man who sexually assaulted a college student in 2013 was sentenced to 2–4 years in prison after being extradited from France, more than a decade after the incident.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, spent years trying to get charges filed, noting that the system failed her despite her early reporting.
The case highlights systemic flaws in how campus sexual assault cases are handled, including the reluctance of prosecutors to pursue charges and the destruction of critical evidence.
The perpetrator, Ian Cleary, admitted guilt and claimed the Facebook message was part of a 12-step program for atonement, though it retraumatized the victim.
The judge considered Cleary’s mental health history and remorse, resulting in a sentence below state guidelines despite the severity of the crime.
The case illustrates how long delays and lack of accountability can allow perpetrators to evade justice, even when crimes are committed on college campuses.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In 2013, Ian Cleary sexually assaulted Shannon Keeler at Gettysburg College, a case that remained unresolved for over a decade due to systemic failures in campus sexual assault prosecution. Keeler pursued charges for years, only to face obstacles including destroyed evidence and prosecutorial reluctance. Cleary was eventually tracked down in France in 2024, extradited to Pennsylvania, and sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025 after a guilty plea. The judge considered Cleary’s remorse and history of mental illness, resulting in a sentence below state guidelines. The case underscores broader issues in how institutions respond to campus sexual violence, including delayed justice, lack of evidence preservation, and the trauma endured by survivors. Keeler described the long years of silence and systemic failure as a painful journey, culminating in a moment of accountability that, though delayed, finally delivered justice.
title: Man Sentenced to 2–4 Years in Prison After Decades-Long Campus Sexual Assault Case
